objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer, colorist

imprint.publisher: There is no imprint for this series of prints. Blake apparently printed A Large Book of Designs copy A on commission for Ozias Humphry in 1796. See the note on Composition Date, below.
imprint.pubplace: LondonThere is no imprint for this series of prints. Blake was living in London at the time of the composition and etching of the plates constituting this series of prints. He was also living in London during the printing of A Large Book of Designs copy A in 1796.
imprint.date: The work is not dated. The plates consitituting this series of prints were etched between c. 1793 and c. 1796. The impressions comprising A Large Book of Designs copy A were printed in 1796. See the note on Composition Date, below.

objdescid.compdate: 1796A Large Book of Designs copy A contains a selection of separate plates and designs for the illuminated books etched between c. 1793 and c. 1796. The impressions constituting A Large Book of Designs copy A were very probably printed in 1796 along with A Small Book of Designs.

objinfo.printdate: 1796See the note on Composition Date, above.
objinfo.objorder: :"Albion rose" copy C (impression 1A in Essick page 24), The First Book of Urizen plate 21, "The Accusers of Theft Adultery Murder" copy G (impression 2B in Essick pages 31-32), Visions of the Daughters of Albion" plate 7 (design only), Visions of the Daughters of Albion plate 1, "Joseph of Arimathea Preaching to the Inhabitants of Britain" impression 1A in Essick page 44, The First Book of Urizen plate 14, America a Prophecy plate d ("A Dream of Thiralatha," impression 1A in Essick page 38). Bentley copy designations and plate numbers are used here unless otherwise stated.
objinfo.objsize: ranging between 27.2 x 20.0 cm. and 7.8 x 10.7 cm.
objinfo.medium: intaglio etching/engraving (objects 1 and 3) and relief etching (objects 2, 4-8), all color printed from the surfaces of the plates and with additional water colors and pen and ink outlining
objinfo.printingstyle: plate surface (objects 1 and 3) or relief (objects 2, 4-8) with color printing
objinfo.inkcolor: All the plates appear to have been color printed without any inking.
objinfo.watermark: 1794 / J WhatmanThis watermark appears only in object 8. All objects are pasted to backing mats, but this watermark can be seen in a raking light. According to Laurence Binyon, The Engraved Designs of William Blake (London: Ernest Benn) 49, object 3 is on Whatman paper with a "1794" watermark. According to Geoffrey Keynes, Engravings by William Blake: The Separate Plates (Dublin: Emery Walker, 1956) 28, object 6 "has a watermark dated 1794." Both Binyon and Keynes may be repeating the watermark dates given in Archibald G. B. Russell, The Engravings of William Blake (London: Grant Richards, 1912) 56, 67.
objinfo.binding: disbound and mounted on matsFormerly bound in half morocco, according to Geoffrey Keynes and Edwin Wolf 2nd, William Blake's Illuminated Books: A Census (New York: Grolier Club, 1953) 89. There is no evidence that Blake bound these prints into a volume; he may have produced them simply as examples of his color printing without any intention of collating them into a series or book.

provenance.name: British Museum
provenance.note: Probably commissioned and acquired from Blake by Ozias Humphry in 1796 with A Small Book of Designs copy A; Humphry's son William Upcott, probably by gift as early as 1797, when Humphry's sight failed, or by inheritance in 1810; possibly sold from Upcott's collection, Messrs. Evans auction, London, 15 June 1846, in lot 277 with America copy H and Europe copy D, possibly among the "original drawings" said in the catalogue to be "inserted" in either or both illuminated books (£7.2s.6d. to the dealer R. H. Evans); sold by Evans to the British Museum in 1856.

desc.objtitle: Albion roseGlad DayThe Dance of Albion, object 1 (Bentley 85.1, Butlin 262.1)

objnote.p: The underlying intaglio etching/engraving is probably in the first state of two; see Essick pages 24-25. The thick color printing obscures the intaglio lines and makes definite identification of the state impossible.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Albion stands in the center of the design with his arms raised horizontally. His legs are spread and his genitals are clearly visible. The ground (apparently a hill or mound rising from right to left) below is mottled, suggesting moss or lichens. Coloring around the figure indicates a sunrise, sunset, or a burst of radiance with beams of light emenating from the figure. A cloud or clouds appar right and left of Albion's lower left leg. Darkness appears in the lower right corner of the design and extends horizontally to the left border between the ground and the radiance. Vertical lines lower right suggest rain.

component.illusobjdesc: The nude Albion stands in the center of the design with his genitals clearly visible. He faces forward with his legs spread apart and his right leg, slightly bent, positioned higher than the left. His arms are raised horizontally in a manner that suggests a cruciform position; his palms are held vertically and face outward from his body. His hair is curly.
The figure stands on a hill or mound rising from left to right. It may be rocky.
Mottled coloring on the ground below Albion suggests moss or lichens.
Coloring around the figure suggests a sky at sunrise or sunset, or possibly a burst of radiance and beams of light emanating from the figure. The effect around his head is halo-like.

Darkness appears in the lower right corner of the design, and extends horizontally to the left border between the ground and the burst of radiance. A cloud or clouds are pictured right and left of the figure's lower left leg. Vertical lines lower right suggest rain.

desc.objtitle: The First Book of Urizen, plate 21, object 2 (Bentley 85.2, Butlin 262.3)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A tightly arranged group of three figures stands against a rocky cliff or mountain, perhaps covered by indeterminate vegetation on the left and in the upper right corner. The figures, from left to right, are (1) a nude woman with long hair who looks down toward, (2) a nude child with short curly hair, probably male, seen from behind, who embraces the female, probably with both arms; and (3) a bearded nude male, likewise looking down toward the child. A massive chain, probably "the Chain of Jealousy" (The First Book of Urizen, Erdman page 80), hangs down the length of his body; its lower end terminates near his (hidden) left foot. The chain's upper end is attached to a large shackle or belt around his chest. He holds a large hammer with his right hand; his right arm, bent at the elbow, rests atop the hammer. The hammer rests upon a pedestal or anvil. The trio likely represents Enitharmon and Los with the child Orc.

component.illusobjdesc: Enitharmon, a nude woman with long hair, stands in contrapposto, right foot forward, while looking down toward Orc. Her head seems to touch the head of Los on the right. Her right arm is at her side and she holds some drapery, perhaps a cloak, with her right hand. This cloth cascades behind her one visible leg.

Orc, a nude and probably male child with short, curly hair seen from behind standing in contrapposto, embraces his mother Enitharmon with both arms raised. His head is turned upward; he may be looking at Enitharmon.

Los, a bearded nude male standing in contrapposto, looks to the left and down toward Orc. His head appears to touch the head of Enitharmon, who stands close beside him. A massive chain, probably "the Chain of Jealousy" (The First Book of Urizen, Erdman page 80) hangs down the length of his body. Its upper end is attached to a large shackle or belt around his chest. He holds (or at least his right hand rests upon) a large hammer; his right arm, bent at the elbow, rests atop the hammer. His left foot is apparently behind the pillar or anvil on which the hammer rests. Only the upper portion of his left arm, apparently raised horizontally, is pictured.

A massive chain, probably "the Chain of Jealousy" (The First Book of Urizen, Erdman page 80) hangs down the length of Los's body. Its upper end is attached to a large shackle or belt around his chest.
Los holds a large hammer vertically. It rests on a pedestal or anvil.
Los's hammer rests on a pedestal or anvil.

Three figures stand against a cliff or mountain, perhaps covered with indeterminate vegetation indicated by mottled coloring to the left of Enitharmon and in the upper right corner above and to the right of Los's head.

Three figures stand against a cliff or mountain, perhaps covered with indeterminate vegetation on the left and in the upper right corner. Some sky is visible upper left; red streaks in the sky hint at a sunrise or sunset.

desc.objtitle: The AccusersThe Accusers of Theft Adultery MurderOur End is ComeA Scene in the Last Judgment: The Accusers of Theft, Adultery, and Murder, object 3 (Bentley 85.3, Butlin 262.2)

objnote.p: The underlying intaglio etching/engraving is probably in the second state of three; see Essick pages 30-32. The thick color printing obscures the intaglio lines and makes definite idenification of the state impossible.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three male figures appear to stand close together, one in front of the other, in a row against a mottled, cloudy or smoky, backdrop. All three figures face slightly forward and slightly to the right, while their heads are turned forward or to the left. The central figure wears a crown and holds each side of his face with his hands, fists clenched. He seems to be fully clothed from head to toe in armor(?) and wears a cloak that goes down the length of his back to his left and ends behind and to the right and the left of his lower calves. His eyes and his mouth are open in an expression of terror or pain, as are the left eye and mouth of the figure to the right. The right-most figure holds a sword to his left with his right hand. His right arm is bent at the elbow and reaches across his torso. His other arm is also bent, and he holds his left hand by his chest. His upper body is nude, while he wears a pair of tight breeches or pants that reaches down to his mid-calves. His right leg is slightly forward of his left leg. The left-most figure wears a costume consisting of what seems to be armor and a skirt (of a Roman military type) that ends just above his knees, leaving his lower legs bare. His right upper arm is visible and seems to be bent. He is probably holding the spear that appears above and to the right of the middle figure. All three figures, probably a king with a guard or soldier on each side of him, appear to be wearing sandals. The mottled coloring of the ground may indicate indeterminate vegetation.

component.illusobjdesc: Three male figures appear to stand close together, one in front of the other, in a row against a mottled, cloudy or smoky, backdrop. The figure in the middle faces forward and holds his face between his hands which he holds as fists on either side of his head. He has a beard and seems to be fully clothed from head to toe in armor(?) with just his feet exposed and wears a cloak that goes down the length of his back to his left and ends behind and to the right and the left of his lower calves. The spikes on his head probably represent a crown; he may be a king. His eyes and his mouth are open in an expression of terror or pain; he may be howling or crying out. He appears to be wearing sandals.

The right-most figure holds a sword to his left with his right hand. He is positioned facing slightly forward and slightly to the right, with his head turned to the left. His left eye and his mouth (one or two teeth visible) are open in an expression of terror or pain; he may be howling or crying out. He appears to be looking at something frightening. His right arm is bent at the elbow and reaches across his torso. His other arm is also bent, and he holds his left hand by his chest; his arms are crossed. He holds a sword in his right hand. His upper body is nude, while he wears tight breeches or pants that reach down to his mid-calves. His right leg is slightly forward of his left leg. His hair is short and curly. He may be a soldier or guard for the central figure.

The left-most figure is visible from behind the figure in the middle. He is positioned facing slightly forward and slightly to the right, with his head turned to the left. His left eye is opened wide, as though he is seeing something frightening. He wears a costume consisting of what seems to be armor and a skirt (of a Roman military type) that ends just above his knees, leaving his lower legs bare. His right upper arm is visible and seems to be bent. He appears to be wearing sandals. He may be a soldier or guard. He is probably holding the spear that appears above and to the right of the middle figure.
The mottled coloring on the ground may indicate indeterminate vegetation.
The background (apparently the sky) is filled with clouds or, more probably, the smoke of war. The red coloring of the smoke above the figures suggests illumination by a fire.
The right-most figure holds a sword.
The top part of a spear appears above and to the right of the middle figure. I might be held by the figure, a soldier or guard, on the left.

desc.objtitle: Visions of the Daughters of Albion, plate 7, object 4 (Bentley 85.4, Butlin 262.4)

objnote.p: Only the design, and not the text, are printed in this impression.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two figures appear on the seashore. One figure, probably male, is seated on the sand or stones near the water. He wears a long gown that covers his knees and lower legs. We see him from the front; his knees are drawn up to his upper chest in a very contracted posture. Given the position of his right foot, his legs are probably crossed at the ankles. His hands rest upon his knees, and in turn his head is bent forward and rests upon his hands. We see only the top of his head, covered with curly hair. This is probably Theotormon, "weeping" (Visions of the Daughters of Alblion, Erdman page 47) near "the margind ocean" (Visions of the Daughters of Albion, Erdman page 51). To the left is a giant wave, shaped like a tongue of flame. Within this wave is a nude female, shackled and chained on her left ankle. Her right leg is apparently extended behind her left. She arches to the right, with her arms bent at the elbows and her hands clasped together just below her neck in a gesture that suggests prayer or supplication. She faces down and apparently looks at the self-enclosed male below her. Her long hair drifts behind her neck and back. She is very probably Oothoon, pleading to her lover. Right and left of the wave in which she appears is a rocky cliff. Wavy lines along the lower margin of the design below both figures suggest small waves of the sea. Far right is the sea, showing a few indications of waves. A sun rises or (more probably) sets on the horizon, with about half of its disc visible. The sun's radiance extends in beams of light upwards to clouds higher in the sky.

component.illusobjdesc: A sun rises or (more probably) sets on the horizon, with about a third of its disc visible. The sun's radiance extends in beams of light upwards to clouds higher in the sky.

A figure, probably male, is seated on the sand or stones near the water. He wears a long gown that covers his knees and lower legs. We see him from the front; his knees are drawn up to his upper chest in a very contracted posture. Given the position of his right foot, his legs are probably crossed at the ankles. His hands rest upon his knees, and in turn his head is bent forward and rests upon his hands. We see only the top of his head, covered with curly hair. This is probably Theotormon, "weeping" (Visions of the Daughters of Alblion, Erdman page 47) near "the margind ocean" (Visions of the Daughters of Alblion, Erdman page 51).

Within a tongue- or flame-like wave is a nude female, shackled and chained on her left ankle. Her right leg is apparently extended behind her left. She arches to the right, with her arms bent at the elbows and her hands clasped together just below her neck in a gesture that suggests prayer or supplication. She faces down and apparently looks at the self-enclosed male below her. Her long hair drifts behind her neck and back. She is very probably Oothoon, pleading to her lover Theotormon. Although her mouth is not clearly open, she may be speaking.
The left foot of the female figure is shackled and chained.
The landscape shows a cliff on the left near the seashore. The lower margin of the design has wavy lines indicating small waves of the sea.
Both stones and sand may be represented below the seated figure. The dark waters of the sea on the right show indications of waves.
The female is pictured within a giant wave of dark water which, in its shape, resembles a tongue—of a creature or of fire.

desc.objtitle: Visions of the Daughters of Albion, plate 1, object 5 (Bentley 85.5, Butlin 262.5)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three nude figures are seen within the mouth of a cave that opens onto the wave-tossed sea. Heavy clouds fill the sky, but fail to cover the disc of the sun. The open area where the sun appears suggests an eye socket, perhaps in a skull outlined by the cave and seen in left profile. Indeterminate vegetation dangles from the roof of the cave. The figures sit or kneel on large stones, or possibly sand below the central female. On the left is a heavily-muscled and bearded male seen in left profile. He sits or squats at the cave's mouth. He looks to the left with wide-open eyes; his face is deeply marked by fear or worse; his hair stands on end. His mouth is open and he may be howling. His knees are drawn up in a contracted position; his right arm is drawn backwards as though bound behind him. Large shackles are attached to both his ankles. Two, possibly three, links of a massive chain descend below his left hip. He may be bound back to back with the female directly to the right. This pair is probably Oothoon, the central female figure in Visions of the Daughters of Albion, and her tormentor Bromion. She kneels, with her body bent down and to the right. Her long hair cascades over her neck and down behind her head. Her eyes may be closed, or at least sharply downcast. Above her and to the right, an extremely contracted figure sits among rocks. This is probably Theotormon, Oothoon's ineffectual lover. His legs appear to be crossed, with the left foot prominently poised below his heavy knees. He faces down so that we see only the top of his head, covered with curly hair. His arms are wrapped around his head, with the left arm bent at the elbow and his left hand, formed into a fist, perhaps clutching his curly hair. His right arm descends along the right side of his hidden face and disappears beneath his left elbow. The design may illustrate the following lines in Visions of the Daughters of Albion: "Bound back to back in Bromions caves terror & meekness dwell / At entrance Theotormon sits wearing the threshold hard" (Erdman page 46). Given this textual parallel, the two figures on the left may be personifications of terror (note the expression on Bromion's face) and meekness.

component.illusobjdesc: The three figures are situated within the mouth of a cave formed of stones and perhaps sand.
We see the sea with waves below and to the right of the female and perhaps behind and on each side of the figure on the left.
The sky, seen above the figures and below the roof of the cave, is filled with dark and heavy clouds.
The round disc of the sun appears through a break in the clouds. The shape of this opening suggests an eye socket, perhaps in a skull seen in left profile formed by the outline of the cave.
Clumps of vegetation of an indeterminate type dangle from the roof of the cave.

The setting for the design—the mouth of a cave—can be considered a structure with both a roof and a floor. Given the shape of the sun, the opening in the clouds around it, and the outline of the cave's mouth, the setting may also suggest a skull seen in left profile.

On the left is a nude, heavily-muscled, and bearded male seen in left profile. He sits or squats on the stony surface of a cave's mouth. He looks to the left with wide-open eyes; his face is deeply marked by fear or worse; his flame-like hair stands on end. His mouth is open and he may be howling. His knees are drawn up in a contracted position; his right arm is drawn backwards as though bound behind him. Large shackles are affixed to his ankles. Two, possibly three, links of a massive chain descend below his left hip. This is probably Bromion, the tormentor of the central female figure in the Visions of the Daughters of Albion, Oothoon. He may also be a personification of terror—see the following lines in Visions of the Daughters of Albion: "Bound back to back in Bromions caves terror & meekness dwell / At entrance Theotormon sits wearing the threshold hard" (Erdman page 46).

A nude female, seen in right profile, kneels on the stones of the cave's mouth. She may be bound back to back to the male to the left. This pair is probably Oothoon, the central female figure in the poem, and her tormentor Bromion. Her body is bent down and to the right. Her face, perhaps with eyes closed or at least sharply downcast, is pointed down; her long hair cascades over her neck and down behind her head. She may also personify meekness—see the following lines in Visions of the Daughters of Albion: "Bound back to back in Bromions caves terror & meekness dwell / At entrance Theotormon sits wearing the threshold hard" (Erdman page 46).
Both ankles of the figure on the left bear shackles, with heavy links of a chain below.

A nude male squats in an extremely contracted posture among rocks. This is probably Theotormon, Oothoon's ineffectual lover. His legs appear to be crossed, with the left foot prominently poised below his heavy knees. He faces forward and down so that we see only the top of his head, covered with curly hair. His arms are wrapped around his head, with the left arm bent at the elbow and his left hand, formed into a fist, perhaps clutching his hair. His right arm descends along the right side of his hidden face and disappears beneath his left elbow.

desc.objtitle: Joseph of Arimathea Preaching to the Inhabitants of Britain, object 6 (Bentley 85.6, Butlin 262.6)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A crowd of male and female figures stands to the left of the main figure on the right who points to the left with his right hand and extended index finger. This right-most figure is an old male who faces left towards the crowd with his body slightly forward. He holds a long staff in his left hand. He is fully clothed in a gown and has a long flowing beard; his long hair drifts out to the right. This figure is probably Joseph of Arimathea preaching to the crowd. The figures in the large group are, left to right, a man embracing a woman around her waist, a woman (seen from behind) with her arms raised and hands together (possibly praying), a bearded man, a young man facing right with his arms crossed over his torso, a woman with her left hand raised near her chest, a man facing away, a young man wearing a cloak over his shoulders and probably looking at Joseph of Arimathea, and a female with her head down and her face obscured by the shoulder of the male to the left. There are slight indications (mostly just heads) of other figures in the background. The limb of a tree extends over the bearded figure of Joseph of Arimathea; the red coloring in the sky suggests a sunrise or sunset. Several vertical lines above the figures on the left suggest (seven?) poles, although these motifs are obscured by the color printing. There may be a hill or mountain rising in the background on the right.

component.illusobjdesc: Joseph of Arimathea stands on the right, facing the crowd on the left and pointing with his right hand and extended index finger to the left above the figures' heads. He holds a long staff in his left hand. He has a long beard and wears a full-length gown; his feet appear beneath its hem. His long hair streams out to the right. Although we cannot see his mouth, he may be speaking.

A large crowd of males and females stands to the left of the large bearded figure of Joseph of Arimathea. There are at least nine clearly pictured figures, with slight indications of the heads of others behind them. Between the sixth and seventh figures from the left is a blue area that may be the gown and shoulder of a figure.

A muscular male (fifth figure from the left) with short curly hair stands at the center of the design facing right towards Joseph of Arimathea. His head is down, and his eyes are either closed or looking down. His arms seem to be crossed over his chest, and his left hand appears below what we see of his right upper arm, and his left index finger seems to point downward. He may be nude or wearing tights.

An old, bearded figure with short hair, fourth from the left, stands left of the central figure. He faces forward and slightly to the right, and his eyes are either closed or looking down. He is fully clothed in a gown that hides his arms and legs.

The female third from the left appears to be praying with her arms raised and her hands clasped together above her head. Her head is bent back, and she faces up and away from the viewer. She is fully clothed in a gown, and the back of her right foot is visible. Her long hair descends in a coil down her back.

The female figure second from the left faces forward and slightly to the left. Her mouth is slightly open; she may be speaking to the male to the left with his arm around her. Her arms are bent upward and she extends her hands and fingers with her palms facing out and up. The fingers of her right hand are slightly spread apart. She is dressed in a long gown. Her hair is long; her facial expression suggests worry.

The left-most male figure stands facing right towards the female next to him. He may be looking at her. He appears to have his right arm wrapped around her, perhaps in an embrace. He is fully clothed in what appears to be tights. His hair is fairly short.

The first figure to the left of Joseph of Arimathea (ninth from the left) appears to be a female with her head down and face hidden. She faces left and is dressed in a gown with her left shoulder prominent. Her left arm is down and appears to be intertwined with (possibly holding) the left arm of the male figure standing to the left. She may be leaning against him. Her hair is long.

A young male figure (eighth from the left) stands to the left of Joseph of Arimathea, primarily facing forward with his body facing slightly to the left and his head facing slightly up and to the right. He appears to be looking at Joseph of Arimathea, the bearded figure far right. His left arm hangs down either at his side and seems to be intertwined with the left arm of the female figure to the right. He has short (possibly curly) hair and appears to be wearing tights and a cloak or a robe that drapes around his neck like a scarf and hangs down the length of his back to the floor. Perhaps we see his right hand, holding the left hand of the figure to the left.

The third figure to the left of Joseph of Arimathea (seventh from the left) is seen from behind. The gender of this short-haired figure is uncertain. Our view of the figure is partly blocked by the male figure to the right, with whom this figure appears to be holding hands or linking arms. The figure's left arm is down at his or her side. The figure is clothed, possibly in a gown or tights.

The female figure just right of the center of the image (sixth figure from the left) stands facing right and forward with her head bent down. Her left arm is bent upward with her palm facing out, fingers spread. She wears a long gown. Her hair is long; her facial expression suggests sorrow or worry.

The coloring of the sky above the crowd seems to indicate clouds and possibly a sunrise or a sunset. Several vertical lines above the figures on the left suggest (seven?) poles, although these motifs are obscured by the color printing of the background landscape and sky. A hill or mountain may rise in the distance on the right.
The shadowy object in the upper right of the image above Joseph of Arimathea seems to be the branches of a tree.
The mottled coloring of the ground beneath Joseph's feet may indicate moss or some other indeterminate vegetation.

desc.objtitle: The First Book of Urizen, plate 14, object 7 (Bentley 85.7, Butlin 262.7)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A muscular nude man is seen from behind facing downward. His blonde hair streams back (or up) toward his feet. The figure may be identified with Urizen or Los. His body and left leg arc to the left; his right leg is bent toward the viewer, exposing the sole of his right foot. His arms are drawn back and his elbows are bent, as if the weight of his body is resting on his hands, which in turn are braced on what may be rock, earth, or clouds at the bottom of the design. His left leg is partly enveloped in a filmy, semi-transparent substance, perhaps clouds. His position, along with his streaming hair, suggests falling, floating, or hovering.

component.illusobjdesc: A muscular nude man is seen from behind facing downward. His blonde hair streams back (or up) toward his feet. The figure may be identified with Urizen or Los. His body and left leg arc to the left; his right leg is bent toward the viewer, exposing the sole of his right foot. His arms are drawn back and his elbows are bent, as if the weight of his body is resting on his hands. His left leg is partly enveloped in a filmy, semi-transparent substance, perhaps clouds. His position, along with his streaming hair, suggests falling, floating, or hovering.
A surface of stone, earth, or clouds seems to support the weight of the figure.

A filmy, semi-transparent substance, perhaps clouds, or Blake's attempt to represent air, partly envelops the left leg of the figure. Other curving lines at the top of the image suggest clouds. The sky(?) left and right of the figure's torso is dark.

desc.objtitle: America, A Prophecy, plate dThe Dream of ThiralathaA Dream of Thiralatha, object 8 (Bentley 85.8, Butlin 262.8)

objnote.p: This impression was printed from a plate, etched in relief, that includes six lines of text. These lines are completely obscured by thick color printing in this impression (1A in Essick page 38) but can be read as blind embossments on the verso of the only known other impression (National Gallery of Art, Washington, impression 1B in Essick pages 38-39). For transcriptions of this text, see Erdman page 59 and Essick page 39.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A partly nude figure, probably the female Thiralatha named in the underlying text etched on the plate (see Editors' Notes), sits hunched over and contracted in the lower center of the design under a large arching tree that curves over her. She is bending forward with her head down on her knee; her left knee and long hair cover her face; the latter cascades over her lower left leg. She faces left, and her left shoulder, arm, and leg are prominent. Her left arm is bent, and her left hand rests on her left knee. There appears to be a band (of jewelry?) encircling her upper left arm. Her left leg is bent at the knee and partially extends in front of her. Her right foot is visible under her left knee and below the drapery or cloth that covers the lower half of her body. The underlying etched text (see Editors' Notes) indicates that she is asleep and dreaming. Two other smaller figures appear to the left. A nude young female figure (possibly Thiralatha as she pictures herself in her dream) stands holding, carrying, or reaching out to an infant, possibly a cherub, who floats above her. This is probably one of the "joyful images" (Erdman page 59) Thiralatha attempts to grasp in her dream. The standing female faces left and up; her head is bent back to look at, or possibly kiss, the infant. She is nude with at least her left arm raised vertically and her right leg bent at the knee and extended slighty backward, right foot on tiptoe. The infant appears to be flying or floating upside down in the air with his legs spread apart and dangling in the air. He reaches down toward the female figure and may kiss her. The sky behind the two embracing figures appears to be partly clear and partly cloudy, extending into darkness to the right of the design behind the tree. The mauve coloring hints at a sunrise or sunset. Reticulated color printing on the ground suggests vegetation of some sort, possibly moss or lichens. The underlying etched text (see Editors' Notes) indicates that the setting is the "Vale of Leutha" (Erdman page 59).

component.illusobjdesc: A partly nude figure, probably the female Thiralatha named in the text etched on the underlying plate (see Editors' Notes), sits hunched over and contracted in the lower center of the design. She is bending forward with her head down on her knee (or knees); her long hair and left knee cover her face. She faces left, and her left shoulder, arm, and leg are prominent. Her upper left arm is encircled with a band, possibly jewelry. Her left arm is bent, and her left hand rests on her left knee. Her left leg is bent at the knee and partially extends in front of her. Her right foot is visible under her left knee and below the drapery, cloth, or gown that covers the lower half of her body. The underlying etched text (see Editors' Notes) indicates that she is asleep and dreaming.

A nude young female figure stands holding, carrying, or reaching out to an infant who floats above her. She faces left and up, and her head is bent back to look at, or possibly kiss, the infant. She is nude with her arms raised vertically and her right leg bent at the knee and extended slightly backward, right foot on tiptoe. Her long hair dangles down her back. The underlying etched text (see Editors' Notes) suggests that this figure is Thiralatha (the large figure to the right) as she pictures herself in a dream.

A (male?) child or infant, possibly a cherub, embraces the nude female figure below. The infant appears to be flying or floating upside down in the air with his legs spread apart and dangling in the air. He reaches down toward the female figure and may be kissing her. The infant's hair is short and perhaps curly. The underlying etched text (see Editors' Notes) suggests that this figure may be a personification of one of the "joyful images" (Erdman page 59) that Thiralatha attempts to grasp in her dream.

A large tree rooted in the bottom right of the design arches over the sitting figure, whose back might be against the trunk. Branches arch over the figure and off to the left. Roots are evident at the base of the tree's trunk.
The mottled coloring of the ground may indicate some sort of vegetation, possibly moss or lichens.
The text etched on the underlying plate (see Editors' Notes) indicates that the setting is the "Vale of Leutha" (Erdman page 59).

The sky and clouds are visible at the upper left of the image behind the two embracing figures, extending into darkness to the right of the image behind the tree. The mauve coloring on the left hints at a sunrise or sunset.
